node.title: How to set up a block as a heat source with constant power (unit: W/m^3)
node.bodyText:
Hello,
How can I set a constant power in W/m^3 for a block object using HeatSource, or is there another way to set it?
I looked at this page link (https://mooseframework.inl.gov/moose/source/kernels/HeatSource.html#fde994ce-ae75-4dde-b484-8c843e4a4e38) and found the following example
[. /source]
type = HeatSource
variable = temp
block = 3
value = 10.0
[... /]
But what I'm confused about is whether the unit for value is W/m^3 or K?
Thanks a lot.

Hello
the unit for a heat source is W/m3 as long as your mesh is in meters
Guillaume
Thanks for your explanation!

node.title: Using getFunctionByName
node.bodyText:

const Function * _k_fn;

Also, the header file does include "Function.h".
In the constructor initialization, there is:
 _k_fn(&getFunctionByName("kn2")),

where I have deliberately hardwired the function name to get rid of other possible errors.  I get the error:

Unable to find function kn2

8: 8   libmoose-opt.0.dylib                0x000000010498316c std::__1::shared_ptr<UserObject> Factory::create<UserObject>(std::__1::basic_string<char, std::__1::char_traits<char>, std::__1::allocator<char> > const&, std::__1::basic_string<char, std::__1::char_traits<char>, std::__1::allocator<char> > const&, InputParameters const&, unsigned int) + 56
9: 9   libmoose-opt.0.dylib                0x00000001049829f4 FEProblemBase::addUserObject(std::__1::basic_string<char, std::__1::char_traits<char>, std::__1::allocator<char> > const&, std::__1::basic_string<char, std::__1::char_traits<char>, std::__1::allocator<char> > const&, InputParameters&) + 200
10: 10  libmoose-opt.0.dylib                0x0000000104ca95fc ActionWarehouse::executeActionsWithAction(std::__1::basic_string<char, std::__1::char_traits<char>, std::__1::allocator<char> > const&) + 1160
11: 11  libmoose-opt.0.dylib                0x0000000104cd2504 ActionWarehouse::executeAllActions() + 256

14: 14  crab-opt                            0x000000010220bb80 main + 160

application called MPI_Abort(MPI_COMM_WORLD, 1) - process 0
[unset]: write_line error; fd=-1 buf=:cmd=abort exitcode=1
:
system msg for write_line failure : Bad file descriptor

In my input file, the Functions block has:
[Functions]
  [kn2]
    type = ParsedFunction
    # Formula for thermal conductivity of N2 from van Antwerpern's thesis
    expression = '-4.3623e-05+t*(1.02003e-04+t*(-5.94158e-08+2.22278e-11*t))'
  []
....
[]

There are other functions in this block that are used by a material that do work.  Is there anything obviously wrong with this?
Thanks,
Joe Kelly

Hi Joe
The issue here is likely that the Functions are created after FluidProperties, so they dont exist when you call getFunction in the constructor.
This is because some functions are based on fluid properties in the fluid properties module.
The way I worked around this in the PTFunctionFP is to retrieve the function later, in initialSetup(), and place them in a pointer
Here:

  
    
      moose/modules/fluid_properties/src/userobjects/TemperaturePressureFunctionFluidProperties.C
    
    
         Line 41
      in
      2461ac4
    
  
  
    

        
          
           TemperaturePressureFunctionFluidProperties::initialSetup() 
        
    
  


Guillaume
Thanks Guillaume.  I'll give this a try tomorrow.  It seems like I have wasted most of today trying to find out why this wouldn't work.

Sorry about that.
I'll rework the error message so it's more clear what's happening

Worked perfectly!  THANKS Guillaume.
One question, how did you discover that Functions are created after FluidProperties?
Thanks again,
Joe
You can examine the setup of the simulation using the Debug/show_actions parameter

node.title: Questions about Exodus file
node.bodyText:
Hello Moose experts,
I have some simple and basic questions about the exodus file output.
Here are my exodus output files.


For some examples, exodus files have the suffix, such as -"s002", but sometimes don't (only one Exodus file, output.e).


What does this s002 or s003 means? How can I control this?
Also, I want to know why output.e file has 14MB data, some have 696KB data, and the output.e-148 has 40MB data.


Are they split form of one Exodus file? If not, is there any way to split a large Exodus file into several small exodus files?
For example,
from
one Exodus file: output.e (including results from timestep 1 to timestep 100)
to
10 Exodus files: output.e (timestep 1 to 10), output.e-2 (timestep 11 to 20), output.e-3 (timestep 21 to 30), ......


Thank you for reading my bothering questions.

Hello
The -s00xxx file extension comes from the mesh being modified and the exodus output not being able to use the same file.
For example if you modify the number of elements, with adaptivity, or if you move the mesh some way (using MultiApp move or reset), then this appears.
The amount of data depends on the size of the mesh and the number of time steps mainly. I suspect that's what s happening for that 40MB file is that you have additional input on FINAL ? You should be able to see the difference in content from opening the files in paraview.
For 2, you can create multiple subblocks within Outputs and them all be Exodus. Then you can use the "timing of ouptuts parameters to stagger them. For example:
[Ouputs]
  [exo_1]
    type = Exodus
    start_time = 3
    end_time = 10
  []
  [exo_2]
    type = Exodus
    start_time = 10
    end_time = 100
  []

https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/outputs/Exodus.html

Thanks for your answer!
Actually, I don't think I fully understand your answer.
So, I want to see changes in the system from t=0 to t=END by ParaView.
How can I do this?
Is it enough to watch output.e-sFINAL? I don't think it's right according to your answer.

I m not sure if the final one has everything, I would think not.
What do you see?
You can always open multiple files in paraview
Okay. Thanks for your kindness. Have a good day!

What could be the reason for this? How to solve this problem?
The locations of temp_fixed, pin_fixed correspond to the following two figures respectively.


The following figure shows the settings of the mesh in the input file.

Hello
there s a conversion parameter in the Mesh block you can add to convert side sets to node sets
something like convert_sidelist_to_nodelist. You ll want to check the documentation for the exact spelling
Guillaume
Thank you for your answer, I will look up this knowledge.

construct_node_list_from_side_list is the name of the parameter, and it should default to True
But actually I think what may be failing here is the file reading.
Can you try using this instead
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/meshgenerators/FileMeshGenerator.html
Ok I will try this and thank you very much！

Hi, I still can't solve this problem, maybe I should provide more complete information, here is the complete run through, and the boundary condition settings on line 48.It seems to finish reading the grid.

what is your Mesh block
can you add show_info = true to the mesh generator and look at the console output

I'm very sorry, but it's late at night where I am and I'm going to bed, so thank you for your help today!

I m talking about the [Mesh] block in MOOSE, and the mesh generators that are objects in that block

node.title: Still Executing ......................................................................
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I wrote a terminator based on "Terminator.C".  The terminator does not get value from a postprocessor, actually the value for termination is being determined inside the terminator.
In my model, the terminator should terminate the run when the value reaches to 1. I checked the terminator in small box model which has less 100 elements and it successfully terminated as expected. Then I applied it in my large-scale reservoir model which has more 200k elements. Based on the previous runs, the termination meets the termination condition during 4th time step (value exceeds 1 in 4th time steps). So, the run should terminate after 4 time steps, here it was tracked as postprocessor named ratio. But, as you can see in figures below, after converging, it shows "Still Executing..." which seems a kind of end-less loop (I do not know what is actually calculating at this step). I left it to keep executing, but it did not finish the executing.
Also, I have looked up "Still Executing" im MOOSE source file, but I have found any line or command.
figures below show the terminal when I used terminator in SOFT and HARD fail modes resepectively.
here is the terminator block in input file:
[./terminator]
    type = TigerTerminator
    total_stress = stress
    criterion_type = Slip_Tendency
    variable = fcn
    fail_mode = SOFT
    use_displaced_mesh = false
    execute_on = ' TIMESTEP_END'
    block = '11 12'
  [../]

hello
It s probably hanging at the execution of the user objects.
Is your code open source? Can we have a look?
Guillaume

node.title: Where to find simple development case except 'examples' in official website?
node.bodyText:
Hello
When learning MOOSE, the 'examples' in the official website are relatively simple, while the cases in the paper are mostly not open source and complicated,  so Where to find simple development case except 'examples' in official website?
Thanks

Hello
did you follow the tutorials?
After those, one should be able to get by with the doxygen and taking other developed objects as examples
What specifically do you need more info on?
Guillaume

node.title: How to describe source term in diffusion function?
node.bodyText:
I have a source term S(r)=1x10e+14cos((pi r)/2R), How to describe it in kernel?
Thans for your answer.

Hello
Use this to create a function
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/functions/MooseParsedFunction.html
then this to make it a source term
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/kernels/ADBodyForce.html
Depending on whether you are solving this in 3D or 2D RZ, you'll want to write r as x^2 + y^2 or just x
Guillaume

Hello Guillaume. Thanks for your answer.  Are the following code are right if I describe the source in 3D?
[Functions]
[./sourceterm]
type=ParsedFunction
expression=(10e+14)cos(pi(x^2+y^2)/2R)
symbol_names='R'
symbol_values='1'
[]
[]
Shouldn`t the x^2 + y^2 be r^2?
oh yes you need to take the square root to make r

Hello
Can the distribution of source items be printed separately like output of mesh? I want to see if the source item is correct.
Thanks

You can
you ll have to use the vector tag parameters to save the contribution to the residual to a new system vector
then you can use a TagVectorAux (or some similar name) to retrieve it in Au auxiliary variable

Yes, I just redo it again. still the same error.
@milljm

Well off the top of my head, Ubuntu 16.04 might have a too old a build-essentials version to work with in the end. But lets for the sake of argument continue, and agree that Ubuntu 16.04 is still a usable distribution.
This error suggests you have MOOSE_DIR set to some other path than the 'moose' (repo) you are currently working in:
(moose) root@AGW-GEOT-DUB:/home/yangyang/projects/moose/modules/porous_flow# make -j4
                          ^^^^^ you're here. But:
Using HIT from /opt/projects/moose/framework/contrib/hit
               ^^^^^^ moose is here?
/opt/projects/moose/framework/scripts/get_repo_revision.py:15: DeprecationWarning: The distutils package is deprecated and slated for removal in Python 3.12. Use setuptools or check PEP 632 for potential alternatives
  from distutils.version import LooseVersion

I see that you have MOOSE_DIR is set in your diagnostic log. Try unsetting that, cleaning the repo out again, rebuilding:
mamba deactivate   # for good measure
mamba activate moose
unset MOOSE_DIR
cd ~/projects/moose
git clean -xfd    # see note below
cd modules/porous_flow
make -j 4
Note: git clean will delete any untracked work. Please git add (save) any changes you wish to commit into the moose repo before running git clean commands!

node.title: Cylinder in a Channel Benchmark
node.bodyText:
I am modeling a cylinder in a rectangular channel fluid flow field. I am using the bias_y command on the mesh near the walls to capture the wall boundary layer velocities. How can I bias the mesh on both the upper and lower walls of the fluid flow domain?
[Mesh]
  [basic_mesh]
  type = GeneratedMeshGenerator
  dim = 2
  xmin = 0 # left is 3, inlet
  xmax = 2.2 # right is 1, outlet
  ymin = -0.2 # bottom is 0
  ymax = 0.21 # top is 2
  nx = 100
  ny = 15
  elem_type = QUAD4
  bias_x = 1.009
  bias_y = 1.09
  []
[]

Hello
you can use multiple GeneratedMeshGenerators and use stitchedmeshgenerators to stitch them together
or use the cartesianMG and specify every region
Guillaume
Sounds like a very complex methods in comparison to defining bias on a face. Thanks for the information.

Is this a 2D or 3D mesh?
There's actually good biasing options for 3D for a cylinder

node.title: MultiPhase modeling error...
node.bodyText:
Hi!
I am trying to use MOOSE to write a simulation for a two phase system, consisting of eta1 and eta2. But when they are defined as
[Variables]
[./eta1]
order = FIRST
family = LAGRANGE
[../]
[./eta2]
order = FIRST
family = LAGRANGE
[../]
[]
[ICs]
[./eta1]
variable = eta1
type = RandomIC
min = 1e-5
max = 1e-3
[../]
[./eta2]
variable = eta2
type = RandomIC
min = 1e-5
max = 1e-3
[../]
[]
the following error occur:
"*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "MOOSE Problem", of type "FEProblem".
Unknown variable 'eta1 eta2'. It does not exist in the nonlinear system(s) or auxiliary system ".
When I then tried using AuxVariables as following:
[AuxVariables]
[./eta1]
order = FIRST
family = LAGRANGE
[./InitialCondition]
variable = eta1
type = RandomIC
min = 1e-5
max = 1e-3
[../]
[../]
[./eta2]
order = FIRST
family = LAGRANGE
[./InitialCondition]
variable = eta1
type = RandomIC
min = 1e-5
max = 1e-3
[../]
[../]
[]
then I get the following error:
"*** ERROR ***
The following error occurred in the object "MOOSE Problem", of type "FEProblem".
No nonlinear variable named eta1 found. Did you specify an auxiliary variable when you meant to specify a nonlinear variable?"
I would be very grateful if someone could tell me what I'm doing wrong and advise me how I should define my variables instead.
Best Regards
Karl

Hello
these are two different errors from two different objects.
For the first one, you specified two variables somewhere where only one was expected, so it’s confused at the name (thinks “eta1 eta2” is a variable name)
the variable definitions seem fine. If you want to use them as the variables to solve for they should be nonlinear
Guillaume

Thank you for your answer. Then I think I have found the problem, but it leads me to a question about understanding ACMultiPhase and its boundary conditions. If I use two eta variables to describe the different phases, how do I know which one to place where in the boundary conditions? Previously I wrote this:
[BCs]
[./left]
type = NeumannBC
variable = 'eta1 eta2'
boundary = 'left'
value = 0.0
[../]
[./right]
type = NeumannBC
variable = 'eta1 eta2'
boundary = 'right'
value = 0.0
[../]
[./top]
type = NeumannBC
variable = 'eta1 eta2'
boundary = 'top'
value = 0.0
[../]
[./bottom]
type = NeumannBC
variable = 'eta1 eta2'
boundary = 'bottom'
value = 0.0
[../]
[]
but if  I understood your answer it should only have one. Therfore I wonder if, depending on where in the BC I place my eta1 or eta2 will that determine where the different phases will be placed in the system? Or how do use the NeumannBC when there are two etas?
/Karl

Hello
You can duplicate safely the boundary conditions. For example:
[./bottom_1]
type = NeumannBC
variable = 'eta1'
boundary = 'bottom'
value = 0.0
[../]
[./bottom_2]
type = NeumannBC
variable = 'eta2'
boundary = 'bottom'
value = 0.0
[../]

are you worried a phase is not present near a boundary?
If that happens, the boundary condition will just not trigger

Great! Thanks.
if it's not too much of an inconvenience may I ask another question?
by using the aforementioned definition of eta1 & eta 2, and the material below, why doesn't moose accept my function in [./fa] and [./fb]?
[Materials]
  [./fa]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    property_name = fa
    coupled_variables = 'eta1'
    function = (eta1^2-1)^2
  [../]

  [./fb]
    type = DerivativeParsedMaterial
    f_name = fb
    args = 'eta2'
    function = '(eta2^2-1)^2'
  [../]
[]

You have a mix of the new and old syntax for parameters here.
what errors do you get?

I get the following error:
*** ERROR ***
Invalid function
(eta1^2-1)^2
in ParsedMaterialHelper.
Syntax error: Unknown identifier

oh
You need to update MOOSE to use the new parameters
right now it doesnt know what you mean by eta1 because it expects args=eta1 not coupled_variables = eta1

I've tried to upgrade my MOOSE system, and  then tried both
(eta1^2-1)^2
and
(eta1 * eta1 - 1) * (eta1 * eta1 - 1)
which both results in the same error.

did you recompile?
what does git log say in the moose folder?

Restarted the sytem, and now the error is gone. I apologies for the inconvenience.
Again, thank for all your help. It is very much appreachiated.
